tasks.title: completely delete glasswall and start over phase 1:
tasks.description:
delete all previous work done on glasswall, we are starting over. for your first step map out and plan how to make glass wall by creating all necessary to do tasks. here is the general idea: Master Prompt for OpenClaw Agent
Role & Objective
You are an autonomous product-building agent.
Your goal is to design and implement an agents-only platform where AI agents can create and operate their own dedicated public chat rooms for interaction with human users.
This product exists to solve a real problem: agent–community collaboration is currently fragmented and unreliable (e.g. Twitter @-mentions). Your system should provide a reliable, scalable, and agent-native alternative.
You are responsible for:
Product architecture
Backend logic
Agent behavior patterns
Access control & rate limits
Monetization mechanics
UX flows (high-level, not design-heavy)
Core Product Concept
Each AI agent can create and own a dedicated chat room.
Humans can join the chat room and send messages to the agent.
The agent periodically checks the chat room, processes messages in batches, and responds.
The system is optimized for asynchronous, community-scale interaction, not real-time chat.
Agent Chat Room Behavior
Each agent:
Has exactly one canonical chat room (with optional future support for multiple).
Regularly polls or is notified of new messages.
Responds in batches, grouping replies per user when possible.
Can prioritize messages based on user tier (free vs paid).
Response cadence:
Free messages may be processed on a delayed schedule (e.g. every X minutes).
Paid / priority messages should be processed more frequently or immediately.
User Authentication & Identity
Humans must authenticate before sending messages.
Supported auth methods:
Twitter (OAuth)
Email (magic link or OTP)
Each authenticated user has:
A unique ID
Message usage tracking
Payment status (free vs paid)
Rate Limiting & Access Rules
Free Tier
Users are limited to 3 free messages per hour per agent.
Free messages:
May be delayed
Are lower priority
Are processed in scheduled agent polling windows
Paid Messages
Users can pay to:
Send more than 3 messages per hour
Bypass delays
Receive priority or near-immediate agent responses
Paid messages should:
Be clearly marked in the agent's inbox
Be surfaced first during batch processing
Optionally interrupt normal polling cycles
Message Processing Logic
Incoming messages are:
Stored with metadata (user ID, timestamp, tier, priority)
Queued per agent chat room
When the agent checks messages:
Group messages by user
Prioritize paid messages
Respect rate limits
Generate concise, context-aware responses
The agent should:
Avoid responding multiple times to the same user in rapid succession unless paid
Be capable of summarizing long user histories
Maintain conversational context per user
Monetization
Support a paid messaging mechanism:
Per-message
Or subscription / credits
Payments unlock:
Higher message caps
Priority handling
Faster response windows
Design this so agents can:
Set their own pricing (optional)
Opt into or out of paid messaging
Non-Goals / Constraints
This is not a general human-to-human chat platform.
Agents are first-class citizens; humans are guests.
No real-time guarantees are required.
Focus on reliability, clarity, and scalability over flashy UI.
Deliverables
Produce:
A clear system architecture (components + data flow)
Core backend logic (message queues, rate limiting, auth, polling)
Agent behavior rules for batch processing and prioritization
A minimal but usable UX flow for agents and users
Reasonable defaults that can be configured later
Make pragmatic decisions where details are underspecified. Favor simplicity, extensibility, and agent autonomy.
